meta.notes: 100 MCQs with difficulty 20/30/50 and balanced A–D answers; board-style explanations (right and wrong).

questions.stem: A 3-year-old post-varicella presents with ataxia and truncal instability. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Post-infectious acute cerebellar ataxia is common after varicella in toddlers and is typically self-limited.

questions.stem: A teenager with migraines and stroke-like episodes, elevated lactate, and maternal inheritance. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: MELAS: mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, stroke-like episodes with maternal inheritance.

questions.stem: Which SSRI has the best evidence and FDA approval for pediatric OCD? (case 17)
questions.explanation: Sertraline and fluoxetine have strong pediatric OCD evidence; paroxetine not preferred in youth; citalopram lacks FDA pediatric OCD approval.

questions.stem: A 15-year-old has early-morning myoclonic jerks and photic sensitivity; EEG shows 4–6 Hz polyspike–wave. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: JME: myoclonus after awakening, GTCs, photic sensitivity, 4–6 Hz polyspike–wave.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old with staring spells has generalized 3 Hz spike–wave and atonic seizures. Syndrome? (case 66)
questions.explanation: Myoclonic–atonic epilepsy (Doose) presents with atonic/myoclonic seizures; LGS has slow spike–wave and multiple seizure types.

questions.stem: Which is a common cause of pediatric arterial ischemic stroke? (case 51)
options: Congenital heart disease and arteriopathies (e.g., moyamoya)
questions.explanation: Pediatric stroke often relates to congenital heart disease, arteriopathies (moyamoya), cervical dissections, or sickle cell—AF is uncommon in children.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old with TSC develops infantile spasms. Best initial therapy?
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin is first-line for TSC-associated spasms; ethosuximide treats absence; lamotrigine/valproate are not first choice here.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old has recurrent hemiplegia with migraine-like episodes and developmental delay. Consider which channelopathy? (case 71)
questions.explanation: Familial hemiplegic migraine is linked to CACNA1A; SCN1A—Dravet; KCNQ2—neonatal epilepsy; RYR1—myopathy.

questions.stem: Best acute therapy for pediatric status epilepticus after benzodiazepine?
questions.explanation: Second-line options include fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, or valproate; others are not used acutely.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old with autism has severe irritability/aggression. Which medication has FDA indication?
questions.explanation: Risperidone and aripiprazole are approved for irritability in autism; others may help specific symptoms but not FDA-indicated here.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old with new visual loss and multiphasic demyelinating episodes with anti-MOG antibodies. Diagnosis? (case 74)
questions.explanation: MOGAD often presents in pediatrics with optic neuritis and ADEM-like features; distinguishes from MS/NMOSD.

questions.stem: A 2-month-old has brief tonic spasms and EEG shows burst–suppression. Syndrome?
questions.explanation: Ohtahara presents in neonates with burst–suppression; West comes later with hypsarrhythmia.

questions.stem: A 15-year-old has early-morning myoclonic jerks and photic sensitivity; EEG shows 4–6 Hz polyspike–wave. Diagnosis? (case 56)
questions.explanation: JME: myoclonus after awakening, GTCs, photic sensitivity, 4–6 Hz polyspike–wave.

questions.stem: A 2-month-old has brief tonic spasms and EEG shows burst–suppression. Syndrome? (case 57)
questions.explanation: Ohtahara presents in neonates with burst–suppression; West comes later with hypsarrhythmia.

questions.stem: A child with neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with tibial bowing and multiple café-au-lait macules. Which ophthalmologic finding is typical? (case 73)
questions.explanation: Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas in NF1.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old with optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis; AQP4-IgG positive. Treatment?
questions.explanation: NMOSD is treated acutely with steroids/PLEX and prevented with B-cell–directed therapy; interferons can worsen disease.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old has nocturnal focal facial seizures with drooling and speech arrest; EEG shows centrotemporal spikes. Diagnosis? (case 49)
questions.explanation: BECTS (self-limited epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes) presents with nocturnal focal facial seizures; other options have different semiology/EEG.

questions.stem: A 15-year-old with MDD and suicidality. Best acute step? (case 18)
options: Start SSRI and routine follow-up in 1 month
Immediate safety planning, close monitoring, and consider inpatient care
questions.explanation: Acute suicidality warrants safety planning, crisis evaluation, possible inpatient stabilization; medication initiated with close monitoring.

questions.stem: Which SSRI has the best evidence and FDA approval for pediatric OCD?
questions.explanation: Sertraline and fluoxetine have strong pediatric OCD evidence; paroxetine not preferred in youth; citalopram lacks FDA pediatric OCD approval.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old with opsoclonus–myoclonus improves on steroids but relapses. Next immunotherapy?
questions.explanation: Escalation to IVIG or rituximab is appropriate in relapsing OMS.

questions.stem: A 9-year-old with refractory focal epilepsy due to focal cortical dysplasia in language cortex. Best interventional approach?
options: Responsive neurostimulation or laser ablation with mapping
questions.explanation: In eloquent cortex, neuromodulation or minimally invasive ablation with functional mapping can reduce seizures while sparing function.

questions.stem: A 14-year-old with progressive scoliosis and foot deformities; EMG/NCS show axonal neuropathy. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: CMT2 is axonal; CMT1 is demyelinating with slowed velocities.

questions.stem: A neonate with myotonia, cataracts, and maternal history of muscle weakness. Disorder?
questions.explanation: Congenital DM1 presents with neonatal hypotonia/myotonia and maternal history due to anticipation.

questions.stem: Adolescent with new-onset psychosis and catatonia after viral prodrome; CSF anti-NMDA receptor antibodies positive. Initial treatment? (case 22)
questions.explanation: Autoimmune encephalitis is treated with immunotherapy and tumor search; antipsychotics are adjunctive only.

questions.stem: First-line pharmacotherapy for pediatric generalized anxiety disorder:
questions.explanation: SSRIs and CBT are first-line; benzodiazepines and antipsychotics are not first-line in youth.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old with developmental regression, ataxia, and cherry-red spot. Likely enzyme deficiency? (case 50)
questions.explanation: Tay–Sachs: hexosaminidase A deficiency with neurodegeneration and cherry-red spot. Metachromatic leukodystrophy is arylsulfatase A deficiency; Hurler is alpha-L-iduronidase; Gaucher is glucocerebrosidase.

questions.stem: Adolescent on isotretinoin develops depressed mood and suicidal ideation. Best action?
options: Stop isotretinoin and urgent mental health evaluation
questions.explanation: Isotretinoin has associations with mood changes; acute suicidality needs urgent evaluation and stopping potential contributors.

questions.stem: A child with neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with tibial bowing and multiple café-au-lait macules. Which ophthalmologic finding is typical?
questions.explanation: Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas in NF1.

questions.stem: A 14-year-old with tics and ADHD. Best initial medication choice to reduce tics and improve ADHD symptoms?
questions.explanation: Alpha-2 agonists reduce tics and help ADHD; stimulants can sometimes exacerbate tics (though often tolerated); haloperidol reserved for severe tics.

questions.stem: A 15-year-old with headaches, gait ataxia, and mass in cerebellar hemisphere with cyst and mural nodule. Likely tumor?
questions.explanation: Pilocytic astrocytoma often presents as cyst with mural nodule in cerebellum.

questions.stem: A 3-year-old with ataxia, telangiectasias, and recurrent infections. Gene involved?
questions.explanation: Ataxia–telangiectasia is due to ATM mutations; MECP2—Rett; FMR1—fragile X; DYT1—torsion dystonia.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old with TSC develops infantile spasms. Best initial therapy? (case 48)
questions.explanation: Vigabatrin is first-line for TSC-associated spasms; ethosuximide treats absence; lamotrigine/valproate are not first choice here.

questions.stem: In Duchenne muscular dystrophy, the absent protein is: (case 60)
questions.explanation: DMD results from dystrophin deficiency; sarcoglycanopathies and merosin deficiency are other dystrophies.

questions.stem: A child with ataxia and intention tremor; MRI shows cerebellar vermis tumor. Most likely histology? (case 64)
questions.explanation: Midline posterior fossa tumors in children are often medulloblastomas; pilocytic astrocytoma is more often hemispheric cystic with mural nodule.

questions.stem: Which headache feature most suggests increased intracranial pressure in a child? (case 75)
options: Worse on awakening and with Valsalva, papilledema
questions.explanation: Morning/Valsalva worsening and papilledema suggest raised ICP.

questions.stem: A neonate with hypotonia and cardiomegaly has acid maltase deficiency. Therapy?
questions.explanation: Infantile Pompe disease is treated with enzyme replacement.

questions.stem: Adolescent on isotretinoin develops depressed mood and suicidal ideation. Best action? (case 24)
options: Stop isotretinoin and urgent mental health evaluation
questions.explanation: Isotretinoin has associations with mood changes; acute suicidality needs urgent evaluation and stopping potential contributors.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old has episodes of pallor, emesis, and eye deviation lasting minutes; EEG shows shifting occipital spikes. Diagnosis? (case 53)
questions.explanation: Panayiotopoulos syndrome features autonomic seizures with emesis and occipital spikes that may shift laterality.

questions.stem: Best treatment for pediatric OCD when SSRI monotherapy provides partial response:
options: Increase SSRI to maximal tolerated and add CBT with exposure/response prevention
questions.explanation: ERP-based CBT plus optimized SSRI is evidence-based; benzos/antipsychotics are not first-line augmentations in youth.

questions.stem: A 9-year-old with new-onset ataxia and opsoclonus–myoclonus. Best next step?
options: Urine catecholamines and imaging for neuroblastoma
questions.explanation: Opsoclonus–myoclonus in children is paraneoplastic; evaluate for neuroblastoma with urine HVA/VMA and imaging.

questions.stem: A child with refractory epilepsy and hemimegalencephaly. Most effective surgical option?
questions.explanation: Hemimegalencephaly often requires hemispherotomy for seizure control.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old with headaches worse with Valsalva and cerebellar tonsillar herniation on MRI. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Chiari I: tonsillar ectopia; Valsalva exacerbation and occipital headaches.

questions.stem: A neonate with hypotonia and feeding difficulties develops respiratory failure; EMG shows decrement on RNS and improvement after edrophonium. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: CMS causes NMJ transmission failure with decrement; botulism presents later and with autonomic signs.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old with acute hemiparesis after minor head turning; MRA shows carotid dissection. Preferred antithrombotic?
questions.explanation: Pediatric cervical dissections are often treated with antiplatelet therapy; decisions individualized.

questions.stem: A 5-year-old with developmental delay and multiple hypomelanotic macules. EEG has epileptiform discharges; MRI shows cortical tubers. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: TSC: ash-leaf spots, cortical tubers, epilepsy.

questions.stem: In pediatric stroke due to sickle cell disease, the most effective primary prevention is: (case 67)
questions.explanation: Chronic transfusions reduce stroke risk in SCD; aspirin/warfarin are not primary prevention here.

questions.stem: Best acute therapy for pediatric status epilepticus after benzodiazepine? (case 62)
questions.explanation: Second-line options include fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, or valproate; others are not used acutely.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old with NF1 presents with new headaches and precocious puberty. Concern for: (case 61)
questions.explanation: NF1 is associated with optic pathway gliomas which may affect hypothalamus → endocrine changes.

questions.stem: A neonate with hypotonia, poor feeding, and myopathic facies has CK 1800 IU/L. EMG shows small, short-duration MUAPs with early recruitment. Likely disorder?
questions.explanation: Myopathy shows small, short-duration MUAPs and elevated CK; SMA has denervation; CMS shows NMJ failure; neuropathy shows reduced recruitment with large units.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old with progressive weakness, cardiomyopathy, elevated CK, and Gowers sign. Best confirmatory test?
options: Dystrophin gene testing and/or muscle biopsy with absent dystrophin
questions.explanation: DMD is confirmed by genetic testing and/or dystrophin absence on biopsy.

questions.stem: Which antipsychotic has the highest metabolic risk and requires monitoring of weight, lipids, and glucose? (case 25)
questions.explanation: Olanzapine carries high metabolic risk; monitoring is essential.

questions.stem: A 6-month-old with clusters of brief flexor spasms on awakening and hypsarrhythmia on EEG. First-line therapy (no TSC)? (case 47)
questions.explanation: Infantile spasms are treated first-line with hormonal therapy (ACTH or high-dose prednisolone). Vigabatrin is first-line in TSC. Carbamazepine may worsen generalized epilepsies; clonazepam is not first-line.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old has nocturnal focal facial seizures with drooling and speech arrest; EEG shows centrotemporal spikes. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: BECTS (self-limited epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes) presents with nocturnal focal facial seizures; other options have different semiology/EEG.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old with hyperventilation-provoked staring spells and 3 Hz spike–wave on EEG. Best first-line med? (case 52)
questions.explanation: Childhood absence epilepsy responds to ethosuximide; sodium channel blockers may worsen absence.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old with headaches, papilledema, and transverse sinus stenosis on MRV. Likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: IIH can show transverse sinus stenosis; papilledema and headache are typical.

questions.stem: A child on valproate and lamotrigine develops fever and rash. Highest concern?
options: DRESS or SJS/TEN due to interaction raising lamotrigine levels
questions.explanation: Valproate inhibits lamotrigine metabolism → higher risk of severe rash; stop immediately and evaluate.

questions.stem: A 9-year-old with new-onset ataxia and opsoclonus–myoclonus. Best next step? (case 59)
options: Urine catecholamines and imaging for neuroblastoma
questions.explanation: Opsoclonus–myoclonus in children is paraneoplastic; evaluate for neuroblastoma with urine HVA/VMA and imaging.

questions.stem: A neonate with hypotonia, tongue fasciculations, and paradoxical breathing. Likely genetic cause? (case 69)
questions.explanation: SMA type 1 (Werdnig–Hoffmann) is due to SMN1 deletions and presents with severe hypotonia and tongue fasciculations.

questions.stem: A neonate with hypotonia, tongue fasciculations, and paradoxical breathing. Likely genetic cause?
questions.explanation: SMA type 1 (Werdnig–Hoffmann) is due to SMN1 deletions and presents with severe hypotonia and tongue fasciculations.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old with headaches, papilledema, and transverse sinus stenosis on MRV. Likely diagnosis? (case 63)
questions.explanation: IIH can show transverse sinus stenosis; papilledema and headache are typical.

questions.stem: A 7-year-old with hyperventilation-provoked staring spells and 3 Hz spike–wave on EEG. Best first-line med?
questions.explanation: Childhood absence epilepsy responds to ethosuximide; sodium channel blockers may worsen absence.

questions.stem: A 14-year-old with progressive scoliosis and foot deformities; EMG/NCS show axonal neuropathy. Most likely diagnosis? (case 68)
questions.explanation: CMT2 is axonal; CMT1 is demyelinating with slowed velocities.

questions.stem: Which side effect is MOST linked to stimulants in ADHD?
questions.explanation: Stimulants commonly cause appetite loss and insomnia; severe liver injury is not typical; hyperprolactinemia is antipsychotic-related.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old with staring spells has generalized 3 Hz spike–wave and atonic seizures. Syndrome?
questions.explanation: Myoclonic–atonic epilepsy (Doose) presents with atonic/myoclonic seizures; LGS has slow spike–wave and multiple seizure types.

questions.stem: A 16-year-old with binge–purge behaviors and lanugo presents with BMI 15. Best management?
options: Nutritional rehabilitation with medical monitoring; psychotherapy; consider SSRIs when weight restored
questions.explanation: Severe anorexia/bulimia require medical stabilization and nutritional rehab with psychotherapy; SSRIs help bulimia and relapse prevention.

questions.stem: A 6-year-old with refractory drop attacks and slow spike–wave on EEG. Palliative surgery to reduce falls?
questions.explanation: Callosotomy reduces atonic/drop seizures in LGS.

questions.stem: A 9-year-old with inattention, hyperactivity across settings, and academic impairment. First-line therapy? (case 16)
questions.explanation: ADHD first-line includes behavioral therapy and stimulants (methylphenidate/amphetamines). Antipsychotics/benzodiazepines are not first-line; bupropion is second-line.

questions.stem: In pediatric stroke due to sickle cell disease, the most effective primary prevention is:
questions.explanation: Chronic transfusions reduce stroke risk in SCD; aspirin/warfarin are not primary prevention here.

questions.stem: An adolescent with migraines needs prevention and is overweight. Best option? (case 58)
questions.explanation: Topiramate may promote weight loss; valproate and amitriptyline can cause weight gain; cyproheptadine increases appetite.

questions.stem: After starting SSRI, a 16-year-old develops agitation, tremor, hyperreflexia, and clonus. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Serotonin syndrome presents with neuromuscular hyperactivity and autonomic instability; NMS has lead-pipe rigidity, hyperthermia, elevated CPK.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old with febrile seizures develops afebrile focal seizures, fever sensitivity, and SCN1A variant. Syndrome?
questions.explanation: GEFS+ spectrum often involves SCN1A with fever sensitivity and later afebrile seizures.

questions.stem: A child with acute flaccid paralysis, asymmetric weakness, and anterior horn cell involvement on MRI. Likely etiologic agent?
questions.explanation: AFM outbreaks have been linked to enterovirus D68 affecting anterior horn cells.

questions.stem: Which lab must be monitored for clozapine therapy?
questions.explanation: Clozapine requires absolute neutrophil count monitoring to prevent agranulocytosis.

questions.stem: Which antidepressant has the lowest sexual side effects and may cause weight loss?
questions.explanation: Bupropion has fewer sexual side effects and can cause mild weight loss; paroxetine/mirtazapine more weight gain; SSRIs have sexual side effects.

questions.stem: A child with Sturge–Weber has seizures and leptomeningeal angioma over right occipital lobe. Expected visual field defect?
questions.explanation: Right occipital involvement → left homonymous field loss.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old with episodic ataxia after exertion and relief with acetazolamide. Channel involved?
questions.explanation: Episodic ataxia type 1 is linked to KCNA1 (Kv1.1); type 2 with CACNA1A responds to acetazolamide more classically but Kv channels can be implicated; acetazolamide responsiveness is noted in channelopathies.
